messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question on Signature // Gordon Reply
messages.msgSnippet: Yeah, these things have a way of getting out of control. The signature on the tsuba is the same as the Nagatoshi listed first in the Kinko Jiten, and as I have
messages.messageBody:
Yeah, these things have a way of getting out of control. The signature
on the tsuba is the same as the Nagatoshi listed first in the Kinko
Jiten, and as I have fuchi-kashira by this artisan, the signature is
very different, and the level of workmanship leaves that tsuba in the
dust...

Gordon

On 2004.1.5, at 05:20 AM, Curran Campbell wrote:

> Wakayama.
>     A list member was kind enough to send me an image
> from I believe the Kinko Jiten (not sure it was this)
> that lists 2 Nagatoshi. No reference signatures, & I
> could only 1/2 translate the entries.
>
> The link below should take you to a larger image of
> this tsuba. It looked a little plain jane to me, and I
> couldn't discern the quality of the iron. I was just
> trying to learn to read the signature, but it became
> more an exercise in verifying whether this is a gimei
> tsuba signature or not.
>     It was auctioned recently, and someone purchased
> it for a little under $350 dollars.
>
> http://tinyurl.com/2qrg9
>
> Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question on Signature // Gordon Reply
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon & Jim, I agreed that the signature looked odd / crude to me. It did not match the Nagatoshi reading I had in Wakayama. A list member was kind enough to
messages.messageBody:
Gordon & Jim,

I agreed that the signature looked odd / crude to me.
It did not match the Nagatoshi reading I had in
Wakayama.
A list member was kind enough to send me an image
from I believe the Kinko Jiten (not sure it was this)
that lists 2 Nagatoshi. No reference signatures, & I
could only 1/2 translate the entries.

The link below should take you to a larger image of
this tsuba. It looked a little plain jane to me, and I
couldn't discern the quality of the iron. I was just
trying to learn to read the signature, but it became
more an exercise in verifying whether this is a gimei
tsuba signature or not.
It was auctioned recently, and someone purchased
it for a little under $350 dollars.

http://tinyurl.com/2qrg9

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question on Signature & Umetada Photo
messages.msgSnippet: Agreed. I looked at the signature very carefully again, comparing it with mine, and it is rather poorly done. Gordon ...
messages.messageBody:
Agreed. I looked at the signature very carefully again, comparing it
with mine, and it is rather poorly done.

Gordon

On 2004.1.3, at 08:16 AM, Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Curran and Gordon,
> Without doing any particular research,  the cutting of the hitsu-ana
> looks rather unskilled and the mei style reminds me of what you see on
> showa-to.  I tend to doubt that it's by the same hand as the
> fuchigashira.  Maybe a later amateur maker or clumsy gimei?
>
> Jim
>
>
>
>   Gordon,
>
>   I believe I located him in vol.1 of the Wakayama set.
>   It provides a number of reference signature examples.
>        If the same guy, signature does not look correct
>   to me. Some things look correct, but others look very
>   off. Also looks as if he chose a different chisel. I'm
>   assuming this tsuba is gimei.
>
>   I don't suppose this is a 'big' guy. Am I mistaken?Why
>   would someone gimei this signature?
>
>   Curran
>
>
>
>   > >
>   > > --- Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:
>   > >> Hi Curran,

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question on Signature & Umetada Photo
messages.msgSnippet: Your signature does look different compared to mine. Mine have tokubetsu-hozon papers from the NBTHK, which would indicate high quality. It seems the fittings
messages.messageBody:
Your signature does look different compared to mine. Mine have
tokubetsu-hozon papers from the NBTHK, which would indicate high
quality. It seems the fittings museum was going to buy these
fuchi-kashira, but went bust before they could. I do not know this
artisan, but he does seem to have a high reputation. Your picture only
shows the signature, what does the rest look like?

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question on Signature & Umetada Photo
messages.msgSnippet: Curran and Gordon, Without doing any particular research,  the cutting of the hitsu-ana looks rather unskilled and the mei style reminds me of what you see on
messages.messageBody:
Curran and Gordon,
Without doing any particular research, the cutting of the hitsu-ana looks rather unskilled and the mei style reminds me of what you see on showa-to. I tend to doubt that it's by the same hand as the fuchigashira. Maybe a later amateur maker or clumsy gimei?

Jim



Gordon,

I believe I located him in vol.1 of the Wakayama set.
It provides a number of reference signature examples.
If the same guy, signature does not look correct
to me. Some things look correct, but others look very
off. Also looks as if he chose a different chisel. I'm
assuming this tsuba is gimei.

I don't suppose this is a 'big' guy. Am I mistaken?Why
would someone gimei this signature?

Curran



> >
> > --- Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:
> >> Hi Curran,
> >>
> >> The signature is Efu ju Nagatoshi. The best
> source
> >> for signtures is the
> >> Kinko Jiten, where this maker is listed. I have
> an
> >> outstanding set of
> >> fuchi-kashira by him. Late Edo period, and worked
> in
> >> Edo.
> >>

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

-----Original Message-----
From: Craig Harris [mailto:benkei@...]
Sent: Thursday, January 01, 2004 7:12 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Question on Signature & Umetada Photo



Wakayama Takeshi, Toso Kodogu Meiji Taikei, 3 vol., 1978. Photos of
signatures of fittings makers. Very handy (as Curran has noted) to get an
idea of whether your piece is close to the "accepted" sho-shin mei.

These photos are cross-referenced in Haynes. Wakayama also did Toso Kodogu
Koza, 8 volumes (1972) and Toso Kinko Jiten (1984) which was referred to in
an earlier message. The last is all Japanese text, no photos, and all of the
information in it is included in Haynes.

Craig

From: Jim Meyer [mailto:tantojim@...]

Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Question on Signature & Umetada Photo

the title?



Jim

Jim,

Its Toso Kodogu Meiji Taiken. 3 Vol. set c.1978 by T.

Koshoyama has a set for $500. I don't know what fair

-----Original Message-----
From: Curran Campbell [mailto:neobliviscar@...]
Sent: Thursday, January 01, 2004 5:19 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question on Signature & Umetada Photo



Gordon,

I believe I located him in vol.1 of the Wakayama set.
It provides a number of reference signature examples.
If the same guy, signature does not look correct
to me. Some things look correct, but others look very
off. Also looks as if he chose a different chisel. I'm
assuming this tsuba is gimei.

I don't suppose this is a 'big' guy. Am I mistaken?Why
would someone gimei this signature?

Curran

Hi Curran,

I don't have the Watanabe set, so I don't know. I have not seen enough
of his work to know what is typical. My fuchi-kashira have sparrows and
bamboo as the motif.

Gordon

Gordon & Rich,

Thanks very much. Any charateristics of particular
with his work?
I don't have the Kinko Jiten yet. Its on a short
list of books to buy once the holiday bills go away.
Would this be in Wakayama's 3 vol Edo work? I'd like
to verify this signature, and can quickly borrow a
copy of Wakayama.

Curran

messages.messageBody:
Hi Curran,

The signature is Efu ju Nagatoshi. The best source for signtures is the
Kinko Jiten, where this maker is listed. I have an outstanding set of
fuchi-kashira by him. Late Edo period, and worked in Edo.

Gordon

messages.subject: Question on Signature & Umetada Photo
messages.msgSnippet: List- Happy New Year to all. I ve posted photos in the Group folder under Curran . The first two are of an Umetada tsuba I use as a reference piece. The third
messages.messageBody:
List-

Happy New Year to all.
I've posted photos in the Group folder under
'Curran'. The first two are of an Umetada tsuba I use
as a reference piece.

The third is a photo of a signature I am trying to
learn to read properly. Current owner thinks its
"TatsuHisa".

http://tinyurl.com/33o6c

Is this correct, or could it be:
TatsuToshi
NagaToshi
(something else?)

Also, can any of the more veteran collectors point me
in the direction of the best references to verify,
date and read up on this maker?
I'm trying to learn how to do this properly by
myself, but find I need a little help on this one.

Thanks in advance,
Curran
